brannvrn.tagline: A VR fire safety simulator that teaches hospital staff to respond to emergencies — without the risk.
brannvrn.challengeText: Hospital employees need fire safety training, but real drills are disruptive and risky. Sykehuspartner wanted a way to train staff in realistic emergency scenarios — letting them practice using fire extinguishers, following evacuation routes, and making quick decisions — all without any real danger.
brannvrn.discoveryIntro: We spent a day at the local fire station consulting directly with firefighters. Their real-world expertise shaped our entire design approach.
brannvrn.insight1: Untrained people make predictable mistakes — we designed our tutorials around preventing these
brannvrn.insight2: Panic overrides knowledge, so repetition and muscle memory matter more than information
brannvrn.insight3: Escape routes need to be learned spatially, not just memorized from a floor plan
brannvrn.insight4: The right equipment depends on the situation — we taught decision-making, not just procedures
brannvrn.designIntro: This wasn't just a simulation — it was an educational tool that needed to teach life-saving skills. Every design decision focused on helping users absorb knowledge naturally while immersed in the experience.
brannvrn.principle1Desc: Information is revealed in stages to prevent overload. Users learn one concept at a time before moving forward.
brannvrn.principle2Desc: Educational content appears exactly where it's needed — integrated into the environment rather than interrupting the experience.
brannvrn.principle3Desc: Users read about equipment first, then immediately use it hands-on — reinforcing knowledge through action.
brannvrn.resultText: We delivered a fully functional VR fire safety simulator to Sykehuspartner. The project received an A grade and demonstrated that VR can effectively teach complex safety procedures in a way that's engaging, memorable, and risk-free. The experience taught me that the best educational tools balance technical accuracy with genuine empathy for how people learn under pressure.
brannvrn.takeaway1: User research transforms assumptions into real insight
brannvrn.takeaway2: Learning design requires empathy for how people absorb information

gonefishing.tagline: A personal logbook for anglers — track catches, locations, and conditions, available offline on the water.
gonefishing.challengeText: Anglers want to remember their catches — where, when, what conditions, what worked. But on the water, you don't have reliable internet, and most apps aren't designed for wet hands and quick logging. GoneFishing needed to work offline-first and be fast enough to use between casts.
gonefishing.discoveryIntro: I drew on my own experience as a freediver and fisherman, plus conversations with other anglers. The key wasn't just logging fish — it was capturing the context that helps you learn and improve.
gonefishing.insight1: Location matters more than species — anglers want to remember exact spots, not just "the lake"
gonefishing.insight2: Conditions tell the story — weather, water temperature, time of day all affect what works
gonefishing.insight3: Photos are essential — a catch without a photo might as well not have happened
gonefishing.insight4: Offline is non-negotiable — cell signal is unreliable on the water, the app must work without it
gonefishing.designIntro: Every design decision prioritized speed and reliability in tough conditions. The app needed to work with cold hands, bright sunlight, and no internet.
gonefishing.principle1Desc: Data syncs when you're back in range, but the app works fully without connection. Your catches are never lost.
gonefishing.principle2Desc: Large touch targets, minimal required fields, and smart defaults mean you can log a catch in under 30 seconds.
gonefishing.principle3Desc: Location, weather, water conditions, and photos are all captured — building a personal database that helps you fish smarter over time.
gonefishing.resultText: GoneFishing started as a personal project to solve my own problem, and it's become a genuine tool I use on fishing trips. Building it pushed me to solve real technical challenges — offline storage, image handling on mobile, syncing across devices. It's a project that combines everything I enjoy: designing for a specific user need and building the solution myself.
gonefishing.takeaway1: Building for yourself means you can't fake understanding the user
gonefishing.takeaway2: Offline-first architecture requires thinking differently about data flow
gonefishing.takeaway3: PWAs can deliver native-like experiences without app store friction

hobbyist.tagline: A social platform that helps people find others who share their hobbies — no swiping, just genuine connections.
hobbyist.challengeText: Making friends as an adult is hard — especially around specific hobbies. Dating apps have solved matching for romance, but there's no good way to find a hiking buddy, a board game group, or someone to practice a language with. Hobbyist aims to fill that gap with activity-first connections.
hobbyist.discoveryIntro: Before designing, I explored why existing solutions fall short. What makes finding hobby partners different from dating or general social networking?
hobbyist.insight1: Dating app mechanics feel wrong for friendships — swiping creates pressure and awkwardness
hobbyist.insight2: People want to do activities together, not just chat — the hobby should be the focus, not the profile
hobbyist.insight3: Trust matters — users need to feel safe meeting strangers around shared interests
hobbyist.insight4: Scheduling is a barrier — even interested people fail to connect if coordinating is too hard
hobbyist.designIntro: Instead of browsing people and hoping they share your interests, Hobbyist flips the model. You browse activities and find people through the things you want to do together.
hobbyist.principle1Desc: Users create or browse activities — like "Sunday morning hike" or "Board game night" — and join based on interest. The activity is the anchor, not the person.
hobbyist.principle2Desc: Meeting strangers can feel risky. Hobbyist includes safety tips, optional identity verification, and activity reviews to build trust over time.
hobbyist.principle3Desc: Once matched to an activity, users have a clear path to confirm attendance, message the group, and see logistics — reducing the friction that kills plans.
hobbyist.aiIntro: Finding the right activity shouldn't feel like work. I integrated an AI chat feature that acts as a personal concierge — helping users discover activities based on their interests, availability, and location. It's a conversational way to explore options without endless scrolling and filtering.
hobbyist.aiFeatureDesc: Users can chat naturally — "I want to do something outdoors this weekend" or "Find me a board game group near Dresden" — and the AI suggests relevant activities. It learns from preferences over time, making recommendations more personal the more you use it.
hobbyist.resultText: Hobbyist is currently in development, with core features designed and built in React and TypeScript. The project has pushed me to think deeply about social dynamics, trust, and how digital products can facilitate real-world connection. It's also been a hands-on exercise in building a full product — from UX research and design through to frontend implementation.
hobbyist.takeaway1: Designing for social interaction requires understanding psychology, not just usability
hobbyist.takeaway2: Personal projects let you own the entire process — research, design, and code
hobbyist.takeaway3: Building in public keeps momentum and invites feedback

holidaze.tagline: A cozy booking app for slow-living getaways — browse, book, and unwind in handpicked cabins and retreats.
holidaze.challengeText: We were tasked with building a modern accommodation booking platform using the Noroff API. The goal was to create an experience that felt warm and inviting — not like a generic booking site, but something that matched the slow-living escapes it showcased. We also needed to work effectively as a three-person team with clear communication and version control.
holidaze.discoveryIntro: As a team of three, we divided tasks based on strengths while staying involved in all aspects — planning, design, and development. Clear communication and disciplined GitHub workflows kept us aligned throughout.
holidaze.insight1: Divided tasks by strength, but everyone touched design, code, and planning
holidaze.insight2: Used GitHub with clear commit messages and documentation to stay in sync
holidaze.insight3: Built in React with Tailwind CSS for fast, consistent styling
holidaze.insight4: Focused on functionality first, with design implemented from our Figma mockups
holidaze.designHeading: Warm, Cozy, and Easy to Use
holidaze.designIntro: The visual design needed to reflect the product — peaceful getaways, not corporate travel. We used warm colors, soft typography, and generous whitespace to create a calm browsing experience.
holidaze.principle1Desc: Earthy tones, rounded corners, and cozy imagery create an atmosphere that matches the slow-living retreats users are booking.
holidaze.principle2Desc: Users can browse, view details, and book with minimal friction. The interface guides them step by step without overwhelming.
holidaze.principle3Desc: Built mobile-first with Tailwind, ensuring the experience feels native whether you're browsing on your phone or desktop.
holidaze.resultText: We delivered a fully functional booking platform that earned an A grade. More importantly, we learned how to collaborate effectively as a team — dividing work, communicating clearly, and maintaining code quality throughout. The project also highlighted areas for growth, including better error handling and accessibility improvements we'd prioritize in future work.
holidaze.takeaway1: Team collaboration requires clear communication and disciplined workflows
holidaze.takeaway2: Consistent styling frameworks like Tailwind accelerate development
holidaze.takeaway3: Recognizing areas for improvement is part of delivering good work

auction.tagline: A web-based auction platform where users can create listings, place bids, and manage their credits in real-time.
auction.challengeText: Build a fully functional auction platform where users can register, create timed listings with images and descriptions, and bid on items. The site needed to handle real-time credit management and provide a smooth experience for both registered users and casual browsers.
auction.discoveryIntro: Auction platforms create urgency and competition. I needed to understand what makes users trust a listing, how they decide to bid, and what information they need to act quickly.
auction.insight1: Trust is everything — users need to see clear images, descriptions, and seller info before risking credits
auction.insight2: Time pressure drives action — visible deadlines and countdowns create urgency to bid now
auction.insight3: Credits must feel tangible — users need to always know their balance and what they can afford
auction.insight4: Browsing before committing — unregistered users should explore freely to build interest
auction.designIntro: Every design decision focused on helping users make confident bidding decisions quickly.
auction.principle1Desc: Each listing shows images, description, current bid, time remaining, and seller details — everything needed to decide at a glance.
auction.principle2Desc: Users always see their available credits, so they know what they can bid without checking a separate page.
auction.principle3Desc: Unregistered users can search and view listings freely. Registration is only required to bid, lowering the barrier to exploration.
auction.resultText: The project earned an A grade. After submission, I revisited the code to improve error handling and form validation — ensuring users get clear feedback when something goes wrong. It reinforced that good UX extends into the details: how errors are communicated, how forms guide input, how layouts stay consistent.
auction.takeaway1: Auction UX is about enabling fast, confident decisions
auction.takeaway2: Trust signals — images, seller info, clear deadlines — reduce hesitation
auction.takeaway3: Post-launch iteration is part of the design process

timerPlanner.tagline: A privacy-first productivity app that combines focus timers and scheduling in one seamless interface — no accounts, no cloud, your data stays yours.
timerPlanner.challengeText: Productivity tools are fragmented — you use one app for timers, another for scheduling, and they never talk to each other. I wanted a single interface where I could plan my day and run focus sessions without switching contexts. And it had to respect privacy: no accounts, no cloud sync, no data leaving my device.
timerPlanner.discoveryIntro: I looked at how I actually work and where existing tools fall short. The friction isn't in the features — it's in the fragmentation and the data trade-offs.
timerPlanner.insight1: Context switching kills focus — jumping between timer and calendar apps breaks the flow you're trying to protect
timerPlanner.insight2: One size doesn't fit all — work/break intervals should be customizable per task, not globally fixed
timerPlanner.insight3: Privacy matters — most productivity apps want your data in their cloud, but your schedule is personal
timerPlanner.insight4: Portability is control — if you can't export your data, you don't really own it
timerPlanner.designIntro: The goal was to make the timer and planner feel like one unified experience, not two features bolted together.
timerPlanner.principle1Desc: Timer and schedule live side by side. Start a focus session without leaving your calendar view — no app switching, no lost context.
timerPlanner.principle2Desc: Drag-and-drop rescheduling, color-coded categories, and recurring events let you organize your week the way you think about it.
timerPlanner.principle3Desc: All data stays in localStorage. No accounts, no cloud. JSON export/import means you own your data completely — back it up, move it, delete it.
timerPlanner.resultText: Timer & Planner is now part of my actual workflow. Building it taught me that the best productivity tools are the ones that disappear — they help you focus on your work, not on the tool itself. The privacy-first approach also reinforced that respecting users' data isn't a limitation; it's a feature.
timerPlanner.takeaway1: Combining related tools reduces friction more than optimizing each one separately
timerPlanner.takeaway2: Privacy-first design builds trust and simplifies architecture
timerPlanner.takeaway3: Building for yourself keeps you honest about what actually matters

piaSalary.tagline: A privacy-first income tracking app with automatic tax calculations — all your financial data stays on your device, stored in Excel files you control.
piaSalary.challengeText: Tracking income across multiple sources shouldn't require trusting a company with your financial data. I needed a tool that could handle monthly earnings, calculate deductions automatically, and show trends over time — all while keeping sensitive information completely private and portable.
piaSalary.discoveryIntro: Most income tracking apps want your data in their cloud. For something as sensitive as salary information, that's a trade-off many people aren't comfortable making.
piaSalary.insight1: Financial data is deeply personal — users shouldn't have to create accounts or trust cloud storage to track their income
piaSalary.insight2: Excel is familiar — people already know how to back up, organize, and share spreadsheet files
piaSalary.insight3: Automatic calculations save time — tax and social insurance deductions follow predictable rules that software should handle
piaSalary.insight4: Bilingual access matters — a tool built for Germany needs to work in both German and English
piaSalary.designIntro: The design prioritized clarity and control. Users should understand their income at a glance and never wonder where their data lives.
piaSalary.principle1Desc: Year-based income overview with trend charts lets users see patterns immediately. No digging through menus — the important numbers are front and center.
piaSalary.principle2Desc: All data lives in Excel files on your device. Load a file to continue, save when you're done. No accounts, no cloud, no wondering who has access.
piaSalary.principle3Desc: Social insurance rates are pre-configured but adjustable. Duplicate entry protection prevents mistakes. The app guides you while staying out of your way.
piaSalary.resultHeading: A Tool That Respects Its Users
piaSalary.resultText: PIA Salary Tracker is now a practical tool I use for my own income tracking. Building it reinforced that privacy-first design isn't a constraint — it's a feature that simplifies both the architecture and the user experience. The project also pushed me to implement internationalization properly, making the app accessible to both German and English speakers.
piaSalary.takeaway1: Privacy-first design builds trust and reduces complexity
piaSalary.takeaway2: Familiar formats like Excel lower the learning curve
piaSalary.takeaway3: Internationalization should be built in from the start, not bolted on later

clicketycart.tagline: A retro-inspired e-commerce storefront with a fast, playful checkout experience — built to make online shopping feel effortless.
clicketycart.challengeText: Build a functional e-commerce frontend that connects to the Noroff API — handling products, cart management, and checkout. Beyond the technical requirements, we wanted to create something with personality: a retro-inspired design that makes shopping feel quick and fun, not like a chore.
clicketycart.discoveryHeading: What Makes Online Shopping Feel Good
clicketycart.discoveryIntro: E-commerce is a solved problem technically, but most stores feel interchangeable. We explored what makes a shopping experience memorable and frictionless.
clicketycart.insight1: Speed is trust — slow interfaces make users doubt whether their actions registered
clicketycart.insight2: Personality differentiates — a distinctive visual style makes a store memorable
clicketycart.insight3: Navigation should be invisible — users expect the logo to go home, the cart to show items, no surprises
clicketycart.insight4: Accessibility is baseline — forms need proper structure, interactions need keyboard support
clicketycart.designIntro: We balanced a playful retro aesthetic with e-commerce conventions users already know. The design stands out visually while the interactions feel intuitive.
clicketycart.principle1Desc: Bold colors, playful typography, and vintage-inspired elements give ClicketyCart a personality that stands apart from generic storefronts.
clicketycart.principle2Desc: Cart updates instantly, totals are always visible, and checkout flows in a clear sequence. No surprises, no friction.
clicketycart.principle3Desc: The logo links home, the cart icon shows item count, categories are one click away. Users never have to think about how to get around.
clicketycart.resultText: We delivered a fully functional e-commerce frontend with a distinctive visual identity. After submission, I revisited the project to improve accessibility — wrapping inputs in proper form elements — and added documentation for maintainability. Small details like making the logo clickable reinforced that good UX often means meeting expectations users don't consciously notice.
clicketycart.takeaway1: Visual personality and usability aren't trade-offs — you can have both
clicketycart.takeaway2: Accessibility fixes are often small but impact real users significantly
clicketycart.takeaway3: Revisiting projects after submission builds better habits than moving on immediately

communityScience.tagline: An accessible, responsive museum website designed for younger audiences — my second project at Noroff and an early step in my development journey.
communityScience.noteBadge: Early learning project — included to show my growth, not my current abilities.
communityScience.briefText: Create a modern, accessible website for a community science museum. The target audience was younger visitors, but the design couldn't be childish — it needed to balance excitement with professionalism. This was my first real challenge in thinking about who I was designing for, not just what I was building.
communityScience.learningIntro: This was only my second web project. I was still grasping the basics — but each challenge taught me something I'd carry forward.
communityScience.lesson1: Responsive layouts — making a site work across screen sizes, not just on my laptop
communityScience.lesson2: Accessibility basics — semantic HTML, alt text, thinking about users beyond myself
communityScience.lesson3: Audience awareness — design decisions should reflect who will actually use the site
communityScience.lesson4: Code organization — structuring CSS in a way I could understand later
communityScience.journeyText: I include early projects like this one because growth matters. Comparing this to my recent work — Hobbyist, GoneFishing, Timer & Planner — shows what consistent learning looks like over time. Every developer starts somewhere, and I believe in being honest about that journey rather than hiding it.

gamehub.tagline: A video game e-commerce concept — my very first coding project and the starting point of my development journey.
gamehub.noteBadge: My first project ever — included to show where I started, not where I am now.
gamehub.briefText: Build an e-commerce website for video games using only HTML, CSS, and vanilla JavaScript. No frameworks, no libraries — just the fundamentals. It was a deep-end introduction to web development: structure pages, style them, make them interactive.
gamehub.learningIntro: This was day one. I was learning how the web actually works — how HTML structures content, how CSS styles it, and how JavaScript makes it respond to users.
gamehub.lesson1: HTML structure — organizing content into semantic elements that make sense
gamehub.lesson2: CSS styling — turning plain markup into something that looks intentional
gamehub.lesson3: JavaScript basics — handling clicks, updating the cart, responding to user actions
gamehub.lesson4: Building without frameworks — understanding what's actually happening under the hood
gamehub.journeyText: The code isn't good. The design didn't match my vision. But that's exactly why it stays in my portfolio. Comparing GameHub to projects like Hobbyist or Timer & Planner shows what two years of learning looks like. Every developer has a first project — this was mine, and I'm not embarrassed by it. Growth requires a starting point.
